Learn more about HMDA

What is HMDA?

The Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA) requires many financial institutions to maintain, report, and public disclose information about mortgages.

HMDA was enacted by Congress in 1975 and is implemented by Regulation C. The Dodd-Frank Act transferred HMDA rulemaking authority from the Federal Reserve Board to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) on July 21, 2011. The FFIEC makes HMDA data and other HMDA resources available to the public through its website.

  • FFIEC website
  • Read more HMDA history
  • Guide to HMDA Reporting
  • CFPB Exam Manual

Highlights from 2012 HMDA data

Each year, HMDA data is analyzed to identify trends in mortgage lending. Here are some highlights from the Federal Reserve Board’s analysis of 2012 HMDA data.

  • Read press release
  • Read entire article
Refinances drove recovery
Mortgage originations were up xx% from 2011, driven primarily by refinancing.
FHA market share fell
Federal Housing Administration (FHA) loans accounted for 27% of first-lien home purchases, down from the 31% in 2011 but still substantial when compared to FHA’s 5% share in 2006.
Higher-priced loans were uncommon with some exceptions
Higher-priced loans are relatively rare overall, with less than x% of first-lien loans exceeded the loan price reporting thresholds. However, 82% of first-liens used to purchase manufactured homes were classified as higher-priced.

Analyze HMDA Data

You can explore HMDA data on your own using our online tools. If you want even more flexibility to use the data in your own applications and projects, visit our API documentation pages.

  • Explore the data
  • Read API Documentation
